awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Addressing Morphological Instability in Topologically Complex Electrocatalytic Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Summary:

Commercialization of renewable energy storage and conversion devices, such as water electrolyzers and fuel cells, requires advancements in both efficiency and operational longevity. Performance as well as cost of these electrochemical energy devices is strongly tied to the electrocatalyst materials that drive the reactions producing energy or fuel. Electrocatalyst materials development has centered on the design of nanoscale catalysts that maximize the exposure and usage of precious metals, i.e. Platinum, of which they are composed. These unique nanoscale architectures, however, are susceptible to multiple mechanisms of degradation, the rate of which is typically inversely proportional to the activity of the catalyst. The goal of this project is to highlight these mechanisms of degradation for electrocatalysts possessing complex nano-architectures. With a better understanding of how these materials degrade, mitigation strategies can be proposed, improving durability and breaking away from the inverse proportional relationship between electrocatalyst activity and durability. Insight developed through the proposed work will have a significant impact on the effort to bridge the gap between highly active and highly stable materials where integration of these morphologically stable yet complex and active electrocatalysts into electrochemical energy conversion and storage devices will yield significant improvements in both precious metal loading and device operational longevity. The proposed work will provide one PhD student and several undergraduate students with a broad and interdisciplinary research experience in interfacial electrochemistry and nanomaterial synthesis for renewable energy technologies. Through a partnership with the Lindy Center at Drexel, the PI will highlight the principles of renewable and carbon neutral energy storage and conversion and promote interest in STEM for grade 4-12 community members.


Technical Summary:

This project will investigate the mechanisms by which three-dimensional, porous, morphologically complex electrocatalytic nanomaterials degrade under relevant electrochemical conditions. The products of this proposed research will highlight the limiting atomic processes and provide insight for the development of mitigation strategies that maintain morphological and compositional integrity with negligible impact on the intrinsic activity of the catalysts. The research objective of the proposed work is to develop a more detailed fundamental understanding of the convolution of electrochemical dissolution and surface diffusion driven coarsening for these three-dimensional nanomaterials that are in a constant state of meta-stability. It is hypothesized that electrochemical coarsening is driven by a dissolution/redeposition process rather than a pure surface diffusion driven process. Through a combination of experimental, local and global measurements, and computational analysis, this project will qualitatively and quantitatively assess the impact of relevant operational parameters on the morphological and compositional evolution of nanoporous materials. This proposed concept has a broad parameter space, composed of a complex web of intertwined interactions. Computational manipulation of this parameter space, through kMC, will be used to explore the underlying physics of electrochemical coarsening: a) the distance along the surface the dissolved species travels before redepositing, b) response time of dissolution and deposition, c) flux of local dissolution for a given UPL, d) the coordination of the preferred defect site, e) flow rate of electrolyte solution (simply by a time-dependent removal of dissolved species), and f) type of surface impurity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to develop an atomistic perspective of electrochemically induced mobility of surface atoms in complex morphology nanoarchitectured catalysts (NAC). Unique nano-morphologies can yield enhanced performance in electrocatalytic materials; however, they are susceptible to new mechanisms of degradation that can limit their commercial applicability. The presence of nanoscale structures with both positive and negative curvature leads to a meta-stability where atomic mobility is driven by thermodynamic gradients. This gradient driven mobility, known as coarsening, can lead to faster material degradation under catalytically relevant operational conditions. We hypothesized that “for topologically complex nanostructures in an electrolyte at room temperature, coarsening is the dominant material degradation mechanism, and is not driven by pure electrochemically enhanced surface diffusion, but rather a dissolution/redeposition process followed by surface reorganization [driven by thermodynamics] to smoothen defects”. To evaluate this hypothesis, the specific project goals included: (1) study the kinetics of degradation via thermal coarsening in Pt-based NACs; (2) deconvolute the contributions of surface diffusion and dissolution/redeposition to the coarsening behavior of NACs; (3) assess the influence of surface dopants, as a function of their surface mobility and standard reduction potential, on coarsening behavior and evolution of structural features (e.g. facet ratios, surface defect density, activity); (4) use the insights from goals (1-3) to design, fabricate and test new NACs that simultaneously possess high activity and stability.

Through a combination of experimental and computational analysis, we have shown that coarsening in complex morphology, open framework NACs during electrochemical operation is due to a combination of surface diffusion and dissolution/redeposition. Using systematic additions of surface dopant species, we have deconvoluted the impact of both surface diffusion driven smoothening and anodic/cathodic dissolution. Key to developing our atomic scale understanding was the design and implementation of kinetic monte carlo (kMC) simulations that can simultaneously account for all mechanisms of atomic mobility. The introduction of dissolution and redeposition as a mechanism of mass mobility into the kMC simulation, which is a novel addition, yielded great agreement between computational output and experimental results. From the kMC simulations, we were able to extract additional useful information such as surface area change, facet ratios, and defect density all with aging time, and correlate them with the experimentally measured change in electrocatalytic activity. These results will help to guide NAC design by highlighting optimal nano-morphologies to enhanced activity and durability, pointing to simple methods for limiting mechanisms of degradation that are specific to NACs.

Using insight developed during completion of this project, we designed a synthetic protocol to make a new NAC, nanoporous nanosheet electrocatalysts. These nanoporous nanosheets have a high activity due to their high defect density and are highly stable due to a balance of slowed elemental surface diffusion and minimized dissolution. To demonstrate its applicability, we synthesized nanoporous Iridium nanosheets and evaluated their activity and stability for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The nanoporous Iridium nanosheets were also integrated into the anode of an acidic polymer electrolyte membrane water electrolyzer (PEMWE) where they showed activity comparable to the best-of-class commercial Ir-based nanocatalysts while surpassing that commercial catalyst in terms of operational durability.

The outcomes of this project, namely a more detailed atomistic level understanding of electrochemical degradation mechanisms in nanoscale catalyst materials, will greatly aid the design of next-generation electrocatalysts. This is critical as any transition to a renewable energy driven infrastructure will rely heavily on electrochemical technologies. Wide-scale adoption of these technologies is predicated on reduction in both capital and operational costs and these costs are greatly influenced by both device efficiency and longevity.

 


Last Modified: 01/05/2024
Modified by: Joshua Snyder
